questions.text: What is blood pressure?
questions.solution: Blood pressure is defined as cardiac output X peripheral resistance.

questions.text: What is the SI unit of blood pressure?
questions.solution:
The SI unit of blood pressure is Pascal (Pa). It is conventionally expressed in mm of Hg.

Note: 1 mmHg = 133 Pa.

questions.text: What is mean arterial pressure?
questions.solution:
Mean arterial pressure is diastolic + 1/3rd pulse pressure. 

The mean pressure is the average pressure throughout the cardiac cycle. It is not equal to the average of systolic and diastolic pressure because, at normal heart rates, a greater fraction of the cardiac cycle is spent in diastole than in systole. The mean arterial pressure is therefore determined by about 60 percent by the diastolic pressure and 40 percent by the systolic pressure.

Mean BP= DBP + 1/3 Pulse pressure
            = DBP +1/3(SBP- DBP)
            = (3DBP+SBP- DBP)/3
            = 2/3 DBP + 1/3 SBP

questions.text: Korotkoffs sounds are due to ______.

choices.text: Increased laminar flow on application of pressure
Closure of aortic valve in diastole
Arterial turbulence on occlusion of vessel
Normal sound that exist even without application of cuff

questions.solution:
Korotkoffs sounds are due to arterial turbulence on occlusion of the vessel.

The streamline flow in the unconstricted artery is silent. But when the artery is narrowed, the velocity of flow through the constriction exceeds the critical velocity and turbulent flow results. Turbulent flow in the partly occluded brachial artery sets up the vibrations (oscillations) of the vessel wall which are heard through the stethoscope and are known as Korotkoffs sounds.

Related Pearl: Phases of Korotkoff Sounds

Phase

Description

K-1

Tapping sound

Corresponds to systolic BP

K-2

Murmur (soft swishing sound)

K-3

Loud and clear tapping sound

K-4

Muffled sound

K-5

Disappearance of sounds

Corresponds to Diastolic BP

NOTE- K-4 (muffled sound) corresponds to DBP in-

  • Adults after exercise
  • Children
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Patients with arteriovenous fistulas for hemodialysis

questions.text: When measuring blood pressure, which of the following is unlikely to show a spuriously high BP?
questions.solution:
The auscultatory gap may give a falsely low recording of systolic BP and overestimation of diastolic blood pressure not spuriously high BP.

In older patients with wide pulse pressure and in some hypertensive patients, the Korotkoff sounds may become inaudible between SBP and DBP, and reappear as cuff deflation continues, this is known as auscultatory gap.

Small cuff size, obesity, and thick calcified arteries can give rise to falsely high BP as in these conditions, vessels are difficult to compress and higher cuff pressure is required to compress them.

questions.text: The systolic pressure in the right ventricle is _______
questions.solution: The systolic pressure in the right ventricle is about 25 mmHg.

questions.text: During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by:
questions.solution:
During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by the elastic recoil of aorta. 

There is stretching of aorta and arteries during systole due to ejection of blood from ventricle. During diastole, the previously stretched aorta and arteries recoil. The volume of blood that is displaced by the recoil furnishes continuous capillary flow throughout diastole.

questions.text: The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by _____
questions.solution:
The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by arterial wall expansion.

Arterial Pulse

  • The blood forced into the aorta during systole not only moves the blood in the vessels forward but also sets up a pressure wave that travels along the arteries. The pressure wave expands the arterial walls as it travels and the expansion is palpable as the pulse.
  • The two major factors that influence arterial pulse are- stroke volume of the heart and distensibility (compliance) of the vessels.

questions.text: Carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to _____
questions.solution:
The carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to pulse pressure. They fire more rapidly to a constantly changing pressure than a stationary one.  

Baroreceptors

  1. Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels
  2. Types based on location
    • Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions)
    • Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions)
  3. Afferents
    • Carotid sinus – a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering)
    • Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the Vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve
  4. Center for Reflex
    • Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius)
  5. Efferents
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature
    • Most sensitive to pulsatile pressure: They work to maintain BP in the range of mean BP, but it is the changes in the pressure they are the most sensitive to. 
    • The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg
    • Maximal activity: 180 mmHg
  6. Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors are denervated
    • Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response
    • 70–110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP and HR
    • >150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of the sympathetic nerve is maximal.

questions.text: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in _______
questions.solution:
Baroreceptor stimulation would result in decreased sympathetic discharge to heart.

The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. 
Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. Thus leading to:

  • Vasodilation and venodilation
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Decrease in cardiac output

questions.text: The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is
questions.solution:
The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 180 mmHg (arterial pressure here and not MAP).
The blood pressure range to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 70- 150 mmHg of mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of:
questions.solution:
Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of Rostral ventrolateral medulla.

The baroreceptors are stimulated by distension of the structures in which they are located. Their afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves to the medulla. These fibers release glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius (NTS). These NTS neurons then excite neurons in the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). These CVLM neurons release the inhibitory neurotransmitter γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) into the RVLM to reduce the firing rate of these. Thus, reducing the sympathetic outflow.

questions.text: Baroreceptor provides ________
questions.solution:
Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.

Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart.

Baroreceptor reflex

  • Increased BP → stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system
  • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation
  • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BP

NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius

CVC - Cardiovagal center

RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla

HR- Heart rate

BP - Blood pressure

questions.text: Afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control goes to?
questions.solution:
Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).

Increased BP stimulates the baroreceptors which provide negative feedback in response to the increase in blood pressure.

Baroreceptor reflex:

  • Increased BP → stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → excitation of CVLM → inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system
  • Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation
  • Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BP

NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius

CVC - Cardiovagal centre

CVLM - Caudal ventrolateral medulla

RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla

HR - Heart rate

BP - Blood pressure

Note:-

Baroreceptors are more sensitive to pulsatile pressure than to constant pressure. A decline in pulse pressure without any change in mean pressure decreases the rate of baroreceptor discharge and provokes a rise in systemic blood pressure and tachycardia.

questions.text: The low pressure receptors are ______

choices.text: Stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

questions.solution:
The low-pressure receptors are stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

The low-pressure receptors are those in the great veins, right and left atria and pulmonary vessels.
Atrial stretch receptors are of two types:

  • Type A: discharge primarily during atrial systole
  • Type B: discharge primarily during late diastole

Distension of the atrial walls→stimulation of atrial receptors → Vasodilation, fall in BP and increased heart rate.

questions.text: Occlusion of common carotid arteries on both sides leads to _____

choices.text: Increase in heart rate and BP
Increase in BP and decrease in heart rate
Decrease in heart rate and BP
No effect on heart rate and BP

questions.solution:
Occlusion of both common carotid arteries causes an increase in HR and BP.

Reduced sinus pressure → response carried to nucleus tractus solitarius via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve → less inhibitory effect on the vasomotor center.
This leads to:

  • Decreased parasympathetic activity to the heart - Increases heart rate
  • Increased sympathetic activity to the heart and blood vessels - Increases heart rate, contractility, constricts arterioles - Increases TPR, constricts veins - increases venous return 

Note: The carotid baroreceptors are located in the walls of the carotid sinus, which is located at or slightly above the bifurcation of the common carotid arteries. So, the occlusion of common carotid arteries is occlusion proximal to the carotid sinus.

If the occlusion is distal to the carotid sinus →increase in sinus pressure → activation of baroreceptor reflex → decrease in BP and HR.

questions.text: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is _____
questions.solution:
The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II.

Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and decreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

Related Pearl: Actions of Angiotensin II

Actions of Angiotensin II

Produces powerful arteriolar constriction and a rise in SBP and DBP

Acts directly on the adrenal cortex to increase aldosterone secretion

Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons

Constricts efferent arteriole, thereby increasing filteration fraction and glomerular filteration rate, when there is decreased renal bloodflow

Direct effect on renal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption

Acts on brain to decrease sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II

Acts on brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH

questions.text: Marey’s law states that _____

choices.text: Heart rate varies directly with blood pressure
Heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure
Heart rate do not have any relation with blood pressure
Heart rate is directly proportional to cardiac output

questions.solution: Marey’s law states that the heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation?
questions.solution:
Increased venous capacitance is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation.

Important effects of increased sympathetic stimulation:

  • Arteriolar vasoconstriction
  • Increased stroke volume
  • Increased heart rate
  • Venoconstriction and decrease in venous capacitance
  • The increase in mean systemic filling pressure is caused mainly by venous contraction.

All these effects together bring about an increased arterial pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide acts by increasing cGMP not by increasing cAMP.

Nitric Oxide

  • Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF).
  • Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • Mechanism of action:
    NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle → vasodilation.
  • Effects of NO:
    • Vasodilation.
    • Neuromodulator in brain.
    • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.
    • In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle.
    • Penile erection.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except ______
questions.solution:
Endothelin-1

  • Potent vasoconstrictor agent.
  • Produced by endothelial cells.
  • They are secreted locally and act in a paracrine fashion.

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

  • Potent vasoconstrictor.
  • Platelet activation.
  • Inotropic effect.
  • Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Have a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart failure.
  • In the brain, regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  • In the kidneys, they are involved in tubuloglomerular feedback→ ↓ GFR.
  • In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors).
  • In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung’s/megacolon).
  • Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene→craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
questions.solution:
The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient.

Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO.

Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.

The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

A "reverse" Bainbridge reflex has been proposed to explain the decreases in heart rate observed under conditions in which venous return is reduced, such as during spinal and epidural anesthesia, controlled hypotension, and severe hemorrhage.

Physiology of blood pressure regulation is an important topic as it is being frequently asked in both AIIMS and NEET examination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. On examination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated blood pressure in this condition?
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for elevated blood pressure(BP) in head injury patients is the Cushing reflex.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

questions.text: All of the following are rapidly acting blood pressure control mechanisms except:
questions.solution:
Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is not a rapidly acting pressure control mechanism, it is an intermediate-acting mechanism.

Regulation of Arterial Blood Pressure:

  • Rapidly acting pressure control mechanism (acting within sec or min)
    • The chemoreceptor reflex.
    • The central nervous system ischemic mechanism.
    • The baroreceptor reflex.
  • Intermediate-acting mechanisms (act after minutes)
    • The capillary fluid shift mechanism.
    • Stress-relaxation of the vasculature.
    • The renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism.
  • Long-term mechanisms (after days)
    • Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)

Note:

  • Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is an intermediate-acting mechanism, but water conservation by RAAS is a long-term mechanism in the regulation of BP.
  • Most rapidly acting: Baroreceptor reflex>>Chemoreceptor reflex

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is correctly matched with an autonomic pathway?

choices.text: Glutamate is released by Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla (CVLM) neurons projecting to the intermediolateral nucleus (IML)
GABA is released by Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) neurons projecting to the nucleus ambiguus
GABA is released by CVLM neurons projecting to the Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla  (RVLM)
Glutamate is released by CVLM neurons projecting to the NTS

questions.solution:
Basic Neural Pathway involved in Regulation of BP

  • NTS: Nucleus Tractus Solitarius
  • CVLM: Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla
  • RVLM (VMC): Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla (Vasomotor center)
  • CVC (CIC): Cardiovagal center (Cardioinhibitory center
  • intermediolateral nucleus (IML)

questions.text: Stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors causes:
questions.solution:
Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies can produce variable effects on heart rate-

  • Direct Effect
    • vagal stimulation → bradycardia
  • Indirect effect
    • Hypoxia →peripheral chemoreceptor stimulation→ hyperventilation and increased catecholamine secretion → tachycardia and increased cardiac output

Chemoreceptor reflex

  • Receptors
    • Peripheral chemoreceptors in carotid and aortic bodies
    • Central chemoreceptors in the medulla
  • Stimulus
    • decrease in- PaO2
    • increase in-Pa CO2, H+ ion conc
  • Afferent
    • IX (sinus nerve of Hering) and X (vagus N)
  • Center for reflex
    • Medulla
  • Efferent
    • Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart vasculature and adrenal medulla
  • Response
    • Direct effect- bradycardia
    • Indirect effect- hyperventilation, tachycardia, vasoconstriction, increased cardiac output and increased BP

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.solution:
Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine.

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing?

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.solution:
There is a decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

  • When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output.
  • Reduced cardiac output, leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing from baroreceptors.
  • As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed leading to increased heart rate.

 

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure
